docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Nov. 21 about repairing ruptured membranes in pregnancy misspelled the given name of a patient treated at New York University Medical Center. She is Lori Melzak-Klein, not Laurie.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Are the Three R's Crowding Out P.E.?'' (Lessons column, Nov. 29), Richard Rothstein highlights the consequences of schools' forsaking physical education requirements for stricter academic standards. Numerous studies have shown the positive impact of physical education on overall health, academic achievement, self-esteem and social skills. It also reduces teenage crime, pregnancy and school absenteeism.
docs.abstract: Bob Tisch letter notes that numerous studies show positive impact of physical education on overall health, academic achievement, self-esteem and social skills (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stephanie and Mark Bishop can visit their premature daughter in the hospital, talk to her nurses and become fluent in the medical jargon that fills the neonatal intensive care unit, all without leaving home. The Internet-based program that provides these ''virtual visits'' results in greater family satisfaction than traditional care, and may result in babies' being sent home sooner, a study at Boston's Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center suggests.
docs.abstract: Study at Boston's Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center suggests that Internet-based program that provides 'virtual visits' by parents of premature babies to neonatal intensive care unit may result in babies being sent home sooner; study is reported in journal Pediatrics (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was a time in the distant past when topics like cancer and pregnancy were taboo in polite company. Thankfully, those days are long gone. So isn't it time to break one of the last and most unwarranted conversational taboos of all? I mean the one about money. Oh, people talk endlessly about investing and so forth, but they are truly tight-lipped about how much money they have and how much they earn. The durability of this taboo is remarkable, given the readiness of so many Americans to talk about their sex lives, substance abuse, tortured upbringings and so forth -- and not only to their friends and acquaintances, but also on television and radio.

headline.main: I'll Tell You My Sins, but Not My Salary

docs.abstract: Daniel Akst column says reluctance of employees to reveal how much they earn to one another makes it easier for employers not to adequately reward superior performance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Some conditions in the beginning of this season of ''Frasier'' have obstructed the earthshaking sexual release that seemed inevitable if Daphne and Niles ever found each other. It was important that they did not appear to abandon their exes for a sexual fling, and important to show that their actions had consequences. On a more practical level, Jane Leeves's pregnancy is limiting options for photographing her, and limiting what she can wear. For a convincing love scene, Daphne will have to appear as dazzling to us as Niles sees her.
docs.abstract: Theresa Muir letter comments on Nov 26 article the television show Frasier

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1869, before James A. Garfield took over the presidency, he observed that ''the developments of statistics are causing history to be rewritten.'' Garfield's prescient statement is quoted in a new book, ''The First Measured Century: An Illustrated Guide to Trends in America, 1900-2000,'' by Theodore Caplow, Louis Hicks, and Ben J. Wattenberg (A.E.I. Press). As the authors note, Americans ''pioneered the measurement of facets of American life that had never been systematically counted before such as crime, love, food, fun, religion and work. . . . The numbers that fill the news -- the Gross National Product, the Consumer Price Index, the unemployment rate, the teenage pregnancy rate, the poverty rate and so forth were inventions of the American 20th century.'' The collection of charts and thumbnail essays, which is the companion volume to a PBS documentary to be broadcast on Dec. 20, are based on census data, government statistics and surveys by the National Opinion Research Center, among other sources. Together, they offer snapshots of social change in the United States.

headline.main: Think Tank; Taking Stock: More Lawyers and Engineers, Fewer Inventors

docs.lead_paragraph: Is there a more elemental expression of feeling than the look on a baby's face? The emotion (or is it instinct?) conveyed by the luminous foundling in Katherine Dieckmann's debut film, ''A Good Baby,'' is the driving force in a movie that has the structure and fatalistic mood of an Appalachian folk ballad. Because the baby girl is remarkably happy and outgoing for an infant who was left abandoned in the woods, she melts the hearts of everyone who comes in contact with her. The foundling is the offspring of a traveling salesman and a naive local teenager he murders after she gives birth in the North Carolina backwoods. Accentuated by the twang of old-style country music, this story of seduction, murder and retribution is a potent blend of naturalism and myth. Although the film, based on a novel by Leon Rooke, is set in present-day Appalachia, its variation on the archetype of the traveling salesman and the farm girl seems almost to take place outside of time.

headline.main: A Traveling Salesman, An Adorable Foundling

docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie A Good Baby, written and directed by Katherine Dieckmann; Henry Thomas and David Strathairn star; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City would become the first jurisdiction in the country to grant victims of rape, domestic violence and other crimes ''motivated by gender'' a broad civil right to sue their attackers under a bill unanimously passed by a City Council committee yesterday. The measure, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to sign into law, seizes the opportunity left open six months ago when the United States Supreme Court struck down a similar provision in a 1994 federal law known as the Violence Against Women Act, ruling 5 to 4 that the general power to regulate crime resides with states and localities, not with Congress. The bill was co-sponsored by at least 33 Council members, giving it more than enough votes to pass when the full Council considers the measure on Tuesday.

headline.main: Council Readies Unique Sex Bias Measure

docs.abstract: New York City Council passes bill that would grant victims of rape, domestic violence and other gender crimes right to sue attackers; measure gives victims up to seven years to to bring suit and permits them to seek attorneys' fees and punitive damages as well as compensation (M)
